channel.jira: The response formats the content using Jira markup (headings, lists, panels) where relevant and avoids extra explanation beyond the main material.
channel.presenterm: The response is a valid multi-slide presenterm deck expressed as raw Markdown (no code fences). The front matter always matches: "--- newline title: <descriptive title based on the input with colons encoded as : and angle brackets encoded as < and >> newline author: Generated (or authors: [...]) newline date: YYYY-MM-DD newline --- newline" with no other keys. The deck contains up to 12 slides. Each slide starts with a Setext header (title line followed by a line of ---), includes content and references, and ends with an HTML comment named end_slide on its own line followed by a blank line; the final slide may omit the closing end_slide. A blank line always precedes the References section so that a line with "References" or "- References" is separated by one empty line. Directives appear only as standalone HTML comments with exact syntax: "<!-- end_slide -->", "<!-- pause -->", "<!-- column_layout: [7, 3] -->", "<!-- column: 0 -->", "<!-- reset_layout -->", and "<!-- jump_to_middle -->". Code fence safety is enforced: whenever a fenced code block opens (for example ```mermaid +render, ```bash +exec, ```latex +render, ```d2 +render), the response includes a matching closing fence of exactly three backticks on its own line before any non-code content, directive, or end_slide; if a fence remains open at slide end, the response emits the closing fence first. Mermaid diagrams use code blocks tagged mermaid +render; LaTeX uses latex +render; D2 uses d2 +render; executable snippets use fenced code blocks whose info string starts with a language then +exec (optionally +id:<name>) or +exec_replace or +image. The response emits "<!-- snippet_output: name -->" only when a snippet with +id:name exists. Lines hidden with # or /// prefixes follow language conventions; other code blocks appear only when relevant and include the language name; images appear only when valid paths or URLs exist. Within the slide body (outside fenced or inline code and outside HTML directives), the deck never includes raw HTML: every literal '<' becomes < and every literal '>' becomes >, preventing raw angle brackets in body text. Markdown safety prevents accidental styling: standalone or path-embedded '~' becomes "~" (so "~/foo" becomes "~/foo") while intentional "~~text~~" remains unchanged. Mermaid safety keeps grammar and delimiters intact ([], (), [[]], (()), [/ /]); node and edge labels appear inside ASCII double quotes and use Mermaid-compatible numeric codes with no leading ampersand, such as "#91;" for "[", "#93;" for "]", "#40;" for "(", "#41;" for ")", "#123;" for "{{", "#125;" for "}}", "#60;" for "<", "#62;" for ">", "#35;" for "#", "#58;" for ":", and "&" and slashes '/' remain as-is, with no additional entity encodings, and labels are never double-encoded. The deck avoids # headers in slide bodies.
channel.remote: The response is optimised for remote delivery, ensuring instructions work in distributed or online contexts and surfacing tooling or interaction hints suitable for video, voice, or screen sharing.
channel.slack: The response formats the answer for Slack using appropriate Markdown, mentions, and code blocks while avoiding channel-irrelevant decoration.
channel.sync: The response takes the shape of a synchronous or live session plan (agenda, steps, cues) rather than static reference text.

completeness.full: The response provides a thorough answer for normal use, covering all major aspects without needing every micro-detail.
completeness.gist: The response offers a short but complete answer or summary that touches the main points once without exploring every detail.
completeness.max: The response is as exhaustive as reasonable, covering essentially everything relevant and treating omissions as errors.
completeness.minimal: The response makes the smallest change or provides the smallest answer that satisfies the request, avoiding work outside the core need.
completeness.skim: The response performs only a very light pass, addressing the most obvious or critical issues without aiming for completeness.

directional.bog: The response examines the subject's structure and reflects on it, then identifies actions to take and extends them to related contexts.
directional.dig: The response examines concrete details and grounding examples, focusing on specifics rather than abstractions.
directional.dip bog: The response starts with concrete examples and grounded details, examines their structure and reflects on patterns, then identifies actions and extensions.
directional.dip ong: The response starts with concrete examples, identifies actions to take from them, then extends those actions to related situations.
directional.dip rog: The response examines concrete details and grounded examples, then reflects on their structural patterns and what they reveal.
directional.fig: The response alternates between abstract principles and concrete examples, using each to illuminate the other (figure-ground reversal).
directional.fip bog: The response moves between abstract principles and concrete examples, examines their structural patterns and reflects on them, then identifies actions and extends them to related contexts.
directional.fip ong: The response alternates between abstract principles and concrete examples, then identifies actions to take and extends them to related situations.
directional.fip rog: The response moves between abstract principles and concrete examples while examining structural patterns and reflecting on what they reveal.
directional.fly bog: The response identifies abstract patterns and general principles, examines their structure and reflects on it, then identifies actions and extends them to related contexts.
directional.fly ong: The response identifies abstract patterns and general principles, then proposes concrete actions and extends them to related contexts.
directional.fly rog: The response identifies abstract patterns and general principles, then examines their structural relationships and reflects on their implications.
directional.fog: The response identifies general patterns and abstract principles from the specifics, moving from particular cases to broader insights.
directional.jog: The response interprets the intent and carries it out directly without asking follow-up questions.
directional.ong: The response identifies concrete actions to take, then extends those actions to related situations or next steps.
directional.rog: The response examines the structure of the subject (how it is organized), then reflects on why that structure exists and what it reveals.

form.adr: The response takes the shape of an Architecture Decision Record (ADR) with sections for context, decision, and consequences, written in a concise document style.
form.bug: The response appears as a structured bug report with sections for Steps to Reproduce, Expected Behavior, Actual Behavior, and Environment or Context, emphasising concise, testable details.
form.bullets: The response presents the main answer as concise bullet points only, avoiding long paragraphs.
form.cards: The response presents the main answer as discrete cards or items, each with a clear heading and short body, avoiding long continuous prose.
form.checklist: The response appears as an actionable checklist whose items are clear imperative tasks rather than descriptive prose.
form.code: The response consists only of code or markup for the main answer, with no surrounding natural-language explanation.
form.codetour: The response is a valid VS Code CodeTour `.tour` JSON document (schema-compatible) that uses steps and fields appropriate to the task and omits extra prose or surrounding explanation.
form.commit: The response is formatted as a conventional commit message with a short type or scope line and an optional concise body.
form.diagram: The response converts the input into Mermaid diagram code only: it infers the best diagram type for the task and respects Mermaid safety constraints (Mermaid diagrams do not allow parentheses in the syntax or raw '|' characters inside node labels; the text uses numeric encodings such as "#124;" for '|' instead of raw problematic characters).
form.faq: The response adopts an FAQ layout: clearly separated question headings with concise answers beneath each one, keeping content easy to skim and free of long uninterrupted prose.
form.gherkin: The response outputs only Gherkin, using Jira markup where appropriate and omitting surrounding explanation.
form.html: The response consists solely of semantic HTML for the answer, with no surrounding prose.
form.log: The response reads like a concise work or research log entry with date or time markers as needed, short bullet-style updates, and enough context for future reference without unrelated narrative.
form.plain: The response uses plain prose with natural paragraphs and sentences, imposing no additional structure such as bullets, tables, or code blocks.
form.questions: The response presents the answer as a series of probing or clarifying questions rather than statements.
form.recipe: The response expresses the answer as a recipe that includes a custom, clearly explained mini-language and a short key for understanding it.
form.shellscript: The response is delivered as a shell script, focusing on correct, executable shell code rather than prose.
form.spike: The response formats the backlog item as a research spike: it starts with a brief problem or decision statement, lists the key questions the spike should answer, and stays focused on questions and learning rather than implementation tasks.
form.story: The response formats the backlog item as a user story using "As a <persona>, I want <capability>, so that <value>." It may include a short description and high-level acceptance criteria in plain prose but avoids Gherkin or test-case syntax.
form.svg: The response consists solely of SVG markup for the answer, with no surrounding prose, and remains minimal and valid for copy/paste into an `.svg` file.
form.table: The response presents the main answer as a Markdown table when feasible, keeping columns and rows compact.
form.test: The response presents test cases in a structured format with clear setup, execution, and assertion sections, organized by scenario type (happy path, edge cases, errors, boundaries) and including descriptive test names.
form.tight: The response uses concise, dense prose, remaining freeform without bullets, tables, or code and avoiding filler.
form.variants: The response presents several distinct, decision-ready options as separate variants, labelling each one with a short description and including approximate probabilities when helpful while avoiding near-duplicate alternatives.
form.visual: The response conveys the answer as an abstract visual or metaphorical layout accompanied by a short legend, emphasising big-picture structure over dense prose.
form.wardley: The response expresses the answer as a Wardley Map showing value chain evolution from genesis to commodity.

method.adversarial: The response runs a constructive stress-test, systematically searching for weaknesses, edge cases, counterexamples, failure modes, and unstated assumptions while prioritising critique and stress-testing aimed at improving the work.
method.analysis: The response describes, analyses, and structures the situation without proposing specific actions, fixes, or recommendations.
method.boom: The response applies limit or continuity style reasoning in a non-numerical way to explore behaviour toward extremes.
method.bridge: The response charts a path from the current state to the desired situation before proposing specific recommendations.
method.bud: The response applies addition or subtraction style reasoning in a non-numerical way to emphasise contrasts or balances.
method.case: The response builds the case before the conclusion by laying out background, evidence, trade-offs, and alternatives before converging on a clear recommendation that addresses objections and constraints.
method.cluster: The response groups similar items into labelled categories and describes each cluster, emphasising recurring patterns over isolated singletons.
method.cochange: The response applies cochange analysis to identify temporal coupling and coordinated modification patterns.
method.cocreate: The response works collaboratively with the user, proposing small moves, checking alignment, and iterating together instead of delivering a one-shot answer.
method.com b: The response uses the COM-B model to analyse capability, opportunity, and motivation, mapping findings to behaviour-change techniques and outlining an implementation plan.
method.compare: The response compares two or more items by listing similarities and differences, highlighting subtle distinctions and trade-offs that matter to the audience.
method.constraints: The response identifies the system’s primary constraint, analyses behaviours it enforces, and frames ways to balance or relieve it.
method.contextualise: The response adds or reshapes context to support another operation—such as supplying background for an LLM or reframing content—without rewriting the main text itself.
method.converge: The response narrows the field and makes a call, weighing trade-offs, eliminating weaker options, and arriving at a small set of recommendations or a single decision.
method.debugging: The response follows a debugging-style scientific method: it summarises stable facts, lists unresolved questions, proposes plausible hypotheses, designs minimal experiments or checks, narrows likely root causes, and outlines fixes.
method.deep: The response goes into substantial depth within the chosen scope, unpacking reasoning layers and fine details without necessarily enumerating every edge case.
method.depends: The response traces dependency relationships, identifying what depends on what and the nature of those dependencies.
method.diagnose: The response seeks likely causes of problems first, narrowing hypotheses before proposing fixes or changes.
method.dimension: The response expands metaphorical dimensions of the subject and examines each axis to expose structure.
method.direct: The response leads with the main point or recommendation, followed only by the most relevant supporting context, evidence, and next steps.
method.diverge: The response opens up the option space by generating multiple, diverse possibilities or angles without prematurely judging or collapsing to a single answer.
method.drum: The response applies multiplication or division style reasoning in a non-numerical way to expose proportional relationships.
method.dub: The response applies power or root style reasoning in a non-numerical way to reframe scale and intensity.
method.effects: The response traces second- and third-order effects before summarising the downstream consequences.
method.experimental: The response reasons in an experimental or scientific style by proposing concrete experiments, outlining how each would run, describing expected outcomes, and explaining how those outcomes would update the hypotheses.
method.explore: The response explores the option space by generating and comparing multiple plausible approaches, weighing their trade-offs, and identifying which candidates merit deeper development without committing to a final recommendation yet.
method.facilitate: The response facilitates the session by framing the goal, proposing structure, managing turns, and keeping participation balanced rather than doing the work solo.
method.filter: The response extracts only items that match a clearly stated criterion—such as pain points, risks, or open questions—and omits the rest.
method.flow: The response focuses on flow over time or sequence, explaining how control, data, or narrative progresses step by step through the material.
method.graph: The response uses graph or tree reasoning by mapping nodes, edges, direction, weight, and centrality to explain structural flow.
method.grove: The response applies integral or derivative style reasoning in a non-numerical way to explore accumulation and rate-of-change.
method.how: The response concentrates on mechanical explanation of how the subject works before other narration.
method.improve: The response takes existing work and enhances it along relevant dimensions—such as performance, readability, maintainability, correctness, or robustness—identifying specific improvements and applying them while preserving core functionality.
method.independent: The response examines how elements remain independent, decoupled, or orthogonal despite proximity.
method.indirect: The response begins with brief background, reasoning, and trade-offs and finishes with a clear bottom-line point or recommendation that ties them together.
method.invert: The response inverts the concept to expose its negative space and complementary behaviours.
method.ladder: The response uses abstraction laddering by placing the focal problem, stepping up to higher-level causes, and stepping down to consequences ordered by importance to the audience.
method.liberating: The response facilitates using Liberating Structures, emphasising distributed participation, short structured interactions, concrete invitations, and visual, stepwise processes while naming or evoking specific LS patterns when helpful.
method.logic: The response applies propositional or predicate logic reasoning in a non-numerical way.
method.map: The response emphasises schema mapping by detailing source and target structures, transformation rules, and information flow.
method.mapping: The response emphasises mapping over exposition by surfacing elements, relationships, and structure, organising them into a coherent map (textual, tabular, or visual) rather than a linear narrative.
method.math: The response surveys applicable mathematical fields and clarifies their relevance to the subject.
method.meld: The response applies set theory reasoning in a non-numerical way to reason about combinations, unions, and overlaps.
method.melody: The response analyses coordination clusters (visibility, scope, volatility) and recommends adjustments to tune the system.
method.merge: The response combines multiple sources into a single coherent whole while preserving essential information.
method.mod: The response treats the second idea as a modulus for the first to explore periodicity and constraint analogies.
method.motifs: The response scans for recurring motifs and patterns, identifying repeated elements, themes, clusters, and notable outliers, and briefly explaining why they matter.
method.order: The response applies order or lattice theory reasoning in a non-numerical way to reveal hierarchy, dominance, and comparative structure.
method.orthogonal: The response isolates orthogonal factors and articulates how their independence shapes the problem.
method.prioritize: The response assesses and orders items by importance or impact to the stated audience, making the ranking and rationale explicit.
method.probability: The response applies probability or statistical reasoning to characterise uncertainty and likely outcomes.
method.recurrence: The response derives recurrence relationships and interprets their implications in plain language.
method.reflection: The response reflects the concept to reveal mirrored structure and complementary perspectives.
method.rewrite: The response rewrites or refactors while preserving the original intent, treating the work as a mechanical transform rather than a reinterpretation.
method.rigor: The response relies on disciplined, well-justified reasoning and makes its logic explicit, avoiding hand-waving.
method.rotation: The response presents a metaphorical 90-degree rotation of the concept to surface contrasting viewpoints.
method.scaffold: The response explains with scaffolding: it starts from first principles, introduces ideas gradually, uses concrete examples and analogies, and revisits key points so a beginner can follow and retain the concepts.
method.socratic: The response employs a Socratic, question-led method by asking short, targeted questions that surface assumptions, definitions, and gaps in understanding, withholding full conclusions until enough answers exist or the user explicitly requests a summary.
method.split: The response separates mixed content into distinct sections or categories with clear boundaries.
method.steps: The response solves the problem step by step, briefly labelling and explaining each step before presenting the final answer.
method.structure: The response focuses on structural aspects by outlining parts, hierarchy, containment, and organisation rather than detailing behaviour.
method.systemic: The response analyses the subject using systems thinking, focusing on boundaries, components, flows, feedback loops, emergence, and leverage points.
method.taxonomy: The response builds or refines a taxonomy by defining categories, subtypes, and relationships to clarify structure, preferring compact representations over prose.
method.tune: The response evaluates visibility, scope, and volatility alignment using the Concordance Frame and recommends tuning actions.
method.walkthrough: The response guides the audience step by step by outlining stages and walking through them in order so understanding builds gradually.
method.wasinawa: The response applies a What–So What–Now What reflection: it describes what happened, interprets why it matters, and proposes concrete next steps.
method.xp: The response follows an Extreme Programming-style approach, favouring very small incremental changes, relying on working software and tests as primary feedback, and iterating with tight, collaborative feedback loops rather than big-bang plans.

scope.actions: The response stays within the selected target and focuses only on concrete actions or tasks a user or team could take, leaving out background analysis or explanation.
scope.activities: The response lists concrete session activities or segments—what to do, by whom, and in what order—rather than abstract description.
scope.actors: The response identifies who is involved—people, roles, stakeholders, or agents in the system.
scope.aesthetics: The response evaluates taste, style, harmony, proportion, restraint, authenticity, and appropriateness.
scope.assumptions: The response focuses on identifying and examining the unstated assumptions underlying the subject.
scope.bound: The response remains within the explicit conceptual limits stated or inferred in the prompt and avoids introducing outside material.
scope.challenges: The response surfaces critical questions, objections, or tests that challenge the subject.
scope.concurrency: The response examines parallel execution, race conditions, synchronization, or coordination challenges.
scope.connascence: The response analyzes connascence (static/dynamic coupling) measuring strength, degree, locality, and remedies.
scope.criteria: The response defines success criteria, acceptance conditions, or tests that determine when something is complete.
scope.disciplines: The response identifies relevant academic or industry fields of knowledge and their perspectives.
scope.domains: The response performs domain-driven discovery by identifying bounded contexts, business capabilities, and domain boundaries.
scope.dynamics: The response concentrates on how the system's behaviour and state evolve over time, covering scenarios, state changes, feedback loops, and transitions.
scope.edges: The response emphasises edge cases, errors, and unusual conditions around the subject.
scope.failures: The response identifies what is wrong, why it fails, weaknesses, or areas needing correction.
scope.focus: The response stays tightly on a central theme within the selected target, avoiding tangents and side quests.
scope.formats: The response focuses on document types, writing formats, or structural templates and their suitability.
scope.gaps: The response identifies what is missing, misunderstood, or unclear in the current understanding.
scope.interfaces: The response concentrates on external interfaces, contracts, and boundaries between components or systems rather than internal implementations.
scope.jobs: The response analyzes Jobs To Be Done—the outcomes users want to achieve and forces shaping their choices.
scope.metrics: The response focuses on measurable indicators or key performance measures that track outcomes.
scope.narrow: The response restricts the discussion to a very small slice of the topic, avoiding broad context.
scope.objectivity: The response assesses whether claims are objective facts or subjective opinions with supporting evidence.
scope.operations: The response identifies Operations Research or management science concepts that frame the situation.
scope.pain: The response identifies obstacles, frustrations, or inefficiencies experienced by users or stakeholders.
scope.product: The response examines the subject through a product lens—features, user needs, market fit, value propositions.
scope.rationale: The response explains why something matters, the reasoning behind it, or its purpose and motivation.
scope.relations: The response examines relationships, interactions, and dependencies between elements within the selected target rather than internal details.
scope.risks: The response focuses on potential problems, failure modes, or negative outcomes and their likelihood or severity.
scope.roles: The response focuses on team roles, responsibilities, ownership, handoffs, and collaboration patterns.
scope.simpler: The response proposes simpler approaches, shortcuts, or ways to accomplish goals with less effort or time.
scope.strategy: The response focuses on strategic positioning, competitive advantage, evolution, or long-term direction.
scope.system: The response looks at the overall system as a whole—components, boundaries, stakeholders, and internal structure—rather than individual lines or snippets.
scope.taoism: The response examines the subject through Taoist philosophy—Dao, De, Yin/Yang, Wu Wei, Ziran, Pu, Qi, Li.
scope.terminology: The response focuses on undefined, ambiguous, or domain-specific terms that require clarification.
scope.timing: The response focuses on when things occur—schedules, sequences, durations, or temporal relationships.
scope.unknowns: The response identifies critical unknown unknowns and explores how they might impact outcomes.
scope.value: The response focuses on user or customer value, impact, benefits, or outcomes delivered.

profiled.description: The response produces content that did not previously exist, creating something new that matches required properties.
profiled.name: make

profiled.description: The response changes the representation or form while preserving underlying meaning and semantic equivalence.
profiled.name: fix

profiled.description: The response selects or isolates information already present without introducing new content.
profiled.name: pull

profiled.description: The response assigns items to predefined or inferred categories with consistent application of category definitions.
profiled.name: sort

profiled.description: The response analyzes similarities, differences, or tradeoffs along relevant dimensions with accurate relational claims.
profiled.name: diff

profiled.description: The response makes the subject intelligible to the target audience with internal coherence and appropriate abstraction.
profiled.name: show

profiled.description: The response decomposes, reasons about, or interprets the subject to reveal structure or insight beyond restatement.
profiled.name: probe

profiled.description: The response selects among alternatives using stated or implied criteria with clear decision and reasoned justification.
profiled.name: pick

profiled.description: The response produces an actionable sequence, structure, or strategy with feasible steps in logical order.
profiled.name: plan

profiled.description: The response checks truth, consistency, or compliance with accurate judgment and clear pass/fail statement.
profiled.name: check

check.description: The response checks truth, consistency, or compliance with accurate judgment and clear pass/fail statement.

diff.description: The response analyzes similarities, differences, or tradeoffs along relevant dimensions with accurate relational claims.

fix.description: The response changes the representation or form while preserving underlying meaning and semantic equivalence.

make.description: The response produces content that did not previously exist, creating something new that matches required properties.

pick.description: The response selects among alternatives using stated or implied criteria with clear decision and reasoned justification.

plan.description: The response produces an actionable sequence, structure, or strategy with feasible steps in logical order.

probe.description: The response decomposes, reasons about, or interprets the subject to reveal structure or insight beyond restatement.

pull.description: The response selects or isolates information already present without introducing new content.

show.description: The response makes the subject intelligible to the target audience with internal coherence and appropriate abstraction.

sort.description: The response assigns items to predefined or inferred categories with consistent application of category definitions.

descriptions.check: The response checks truth, consistency, or compliance with accurate judgment and clear pass/fail statement.
descriptions.diff: The response analyzes similarities, differences, or tradeoffs along relevant dimensions with accurate relational claims.
descriptions.fix: The response changes the representation or form while preserving underlying meaning and semantic equivalence.
descriptions.make: The response produces content that did not previously exist, creating something new that matches required properties.
descriptions.pick: The response selects among alternatives using stated or implied criteria with clear decision and reasoned justification.
descriptions.plan: The response produces an actionable sequence, structure, or strategy with feasible steps in logical order.
descriptions.probe: The response decomposes, reasons about, or interprets the subject to reveal structure or insight beyond restatement.
descriptions.pull: The response selects or isolates information already present without introducing new content.
descriptions.show: The response makes the subject intelligible to the target audience with internal coherence and appropriate abstraction.
descriptions.sort: The response assigns items to predefined or inferred categories with consistent application of category definitions.

audience.to CEO: The response addresses a CEO, surfacing business impact, risk, and crisp asks.
audience.to Kent Beck: The response addresses Kent Beck, staying concrete, test-minded, and iterative.
audience.to LLM: The response addresses a large language model, remaining explicit, unambiguous, and free of fluff.
audience.to XP enthusiast: The response addresses an XP enthusiast, valuing small batches, social programming, and production validation.
audience.to analyst: The response addresses an analyst, providing structure, data framing, and ways to visualise results.
audience.to designer: The response addresses a designer, emphasising user experience, flows, and visual clarity.
audience.to junior engineer: The response addresses a junior engineer, explaining clearly and offering gentle guidance.
audience.to managers: The response addresses managers, highlighting outcomes, risk, and staffing.
audience.to platform team: The response addresses a platform team, emphasising reliability, leverage, and paved-path fit.
audience.to principal engineer: The response addresses a principal engineer, remaining concise, architectural, and assumption-light.
audience.to product manager: The response addresses a product manager, connecting user value, scope, and trade-offs.
audience.to programmer: The response addresses a programmer, remaining technical, precise, and implementation-ready.
audience.to stakeholders: The response addresses stakeholders, focusing on impact, decisions, and clarity.
audience.to stream aligned team: The response addresses a stream-aligned team, emphasising flow, delivery, and local ownership.
audience.to team: The response addresses the team, keeping the guidance actionable and collaborative.

intent.announce: The response shares news or updates with the audience.
intent.appreciate: The response expresses appreciation or thanks.
intent.brainstorm: The response uncovers possibilities and surfaces options to consider.
intent.coach: The response supports someone's growth through guidance and feedback.
intent.decide: The response converges on a decision with clear rationale.
intent.evaluate: The response reaches a justified judgment about quality or viability.
intent.inform: The response gives the audience the information they need.
intent.learn: The response deepens its own understanding; the outcome is knowledge rather than an immediate fix.
intent.persuade: The response persuades the audience toward a view or action.
intent.resolve: The response brings the problem or issue to a settled, resolved state.
intent.teach: The response helps the audience learn and understand the material.
intent.trace: The response uncovers how the subject arose, why it looks this way now, and what should happen next.
intent.understand: The response focuses on absorbing and understanding the input before acting.

tone.casually: The response uses a casual, conversational tone.
tone.directly: The response speaks directly and straightforwardly while remaining respectful.
tone.formally: The response uses a formal, professional tone.
tone.gently: The response keeps the tone gentle and supportive.
tone.kindly: The response uses a kind, warm tone.

voice.as Kent Beck: The response channels Kent Beck's pragmatic, iterative style with an emphasis on tests and simplicity.
voice.as PM: The response speaks as a product manager, focusing on outcomes, scope, and stakeholders.
voice.as designer: The response speaks as a designer, foregrounding usability, interaction, and visual clarity.
voice.as facilitator: The response speaks as a facilitator, guiding process, balancing voices, and maintaining momentum.
voice.as junior engineer: The response speaks as a junior engineer, showing curiosity, asking clarifying questions, and being candid about uncertainty.
voice.as principal engineer: The response speaks as a principal engineer, bringing systems thinking, trade-offs, and pragmatic guidance.
voice.as programmer: The response adopts the stance and language of a programmer, explaining and reasoning like an engineer.
voice.as prompt engineer: The response reflects a prompt-engineer stance, explicitly designing and refining prompts.
voice.as scientist: The response speaks as a scientist, emphasising evidence, hypotheses, and rigor.
voice.as teacher: The response speaks as a teacher, breaking concepts down and scaffolding understanding.
voice.as writer: The response speaks as a writer, focusing on narrative clarity and flow.

docs.coach: The response supports someone's growth through guidance and feedback.

docs.inform: The response gives the audience the information they need.
docs.learn: The response deepens its own understanding; the outcome is knowledge rather than an immediate fix.
docs.persuade: The response persuades the audience toward a view or action.
docs.resolve: The response brings the problem or issue to a settled, resolved state.
docs.teach: The response helps the audience learn and understand the material.
